case_name: Ananda Bazar Patrika (P) Ltd. v. Its workmen

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 633 of 1962 filed by Ananda Bazar Patrika P Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 633 of 1962. Appeal by special leave from the award dated December 8, 1959,

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from award dated December 8, 1959 of Second Labour Court, West Bengal in Case No. VIII-C-226 of 1958

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the award dated December 8, 1959, of the, Second Labour Court, West Bengal, in Case No. VIII-C-226 of 1958. V. Viswanatha Sastri and K. Baldev Mehta, for the

facts.text: Ananda Bazar Patrika P Ltd is a private limited company printing and publishing Ananda Bazar Patrika (Bengali Daily), Desh (Bengali Weekly), Hindustan Standard (English daily)

anchor.surface_text: This appeal arises from an industrial dispute between the appellant, the Ananda Bazar Patrika  P  Ltd., and the respondents, its workmen. The appellant is a private limited companypany and carries on the business of printing and publishing newspapers, namely, Ananda Bazar Patrika which is a Bengali Daily, Desh which is a Bengali Weekly, and Hindustan Standard which is an English daily newspaper,

facts.text: Mr. Pulakesh De Sarkar appointed as journalist by management in March 1940 and worked until discharged on May 15, 1958

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Pulakesh De Sarkar was appointed by the management of the appellant as journalist in March, 1940, and has been working with the appellant since then until he was discharged from service by the appellant on May 15, 1958.

facts.text: Union of appellant's employees raised industrial dispute over discharge of Mr. Sarkar seeking reinstatement and/or compensation

anchor.surface_text: The Union of the appellants employees took up this discharge and raised an industrial dispute about it. In was urged by the Union that the discharge. of Mr. Sarkars services was illegal and that he was entitled to reinstatement and or companypensation.

facts.text: Dispute referred by Government of West Bengal to Second Labour Court on September 25, 1958

anchor.surface_text: This dispute was referred by the Government of West Bengal for adjudication to the Second Labour Court on September 25, 1958. By its award pronounced on December 8, 1959, the Labour Court has directed the appellant to reinstate Mr. Sarkar

facts.text: Labour Court award on December 8, 1959 directed reinstatement of Mr. Sarkar and payment of emoluments for forced unemployment, adjusting payments made on January 27, 1959

anchor.surface_text: By its award pronounced on December 8, 1959, the Labour Court has directed the appellant to reinstate Mr. Sarkar and pay him his emoluments for the period of his forced unemployment. It appears that on January 27, 1959, the appellant had paid some moneys to Mr. Sarkar,

facts.text: Appellant paid some moneys to Mr. Sarkar on January 27, 1959

anchor.surface_text: It appears that on January 27, 1959, the appellant had paid some moneys to Mr. Sarkar, and so, the award directs that in paying emoluments to Mr. Sarkar under the provisions of the award, adjustments should be made

facts.text: On December 16, 1957, Mr. Shibdas Bhattacharjee, Chief Reporter of Ananda Bazar Patrika, proceeded on leave and appointed Mr. Madhusudan Chakravorty as temporary Chief Reporter

anchor.surface_text: It appears that on December 16, 1957, Mr. Shibdas Bhattacharjee who was the Chief Reporter of the Ananda Bazar Patrika, proceeded on leave. Before going on leave, Mr. Bhattacharjee appointed Mr. Madhusudan Chakravorty to work as Chief Reporter temporarily during his absence.

facts.text: Mr. Bhattacharjee wrote letter appointing Mr. Chakravorty, sent copies to Editor, News Editor, Chief Accountant, Reporting Department, addressed to Managing Director, copy on Notice Board

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, he wrote a letter to that effect and sent its companyies to the Editor of the Ananda Bazar Patrika, to the News Editor of the said Paper, to the Chief Accountant and to the Reporting Department. The letter was addressed to the Managing Director.

facts.text: Mr. Sarkar objected to arrangement, interviewed Managing Director who explained it was at instance of Accounts Department for financial transactions

anchor.surface_text: of the Ananda Bazar Patrika, and a companyy of it was hung on the Notice Board of the Reporting Section of the Ananda Bazar Patrika Mr. Sarkar who was working as one of the Reporters took exception to this arrangement and interviewed the Managing Director to request him to cancel the said arrangement.

facts.text: On December 20, 1957, Mr. Sarkar wrote letter to Managing Director objecting strongly, hung copy on Notice Board, stated he would decide own assignments

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sarkar wag number satisfied with the interview and so, he proceeded to write a letter to the Managing Director and hung up a companyy of this letter on the Notice Board. In this letter he took strong exception to the arrangement made by Mr. Bhattacharjee

facts.text: Mr. Sarkar ignored assignments from Acting Chief Reporter Mr. Chakravorty

anchor.surface_text: True to the threat held out by him in his letter, Mr. Sarkar appeared to ignore the assignments allotted to him by the Acting Chief Reporter, Mr. Chakravorty.

facts.text: On December 31, 1957, Managing Director wrote to Mr. Sarkar to show cause why action for gross misconduct

anchor.surface_text: When this matter was brought to the numberice of the Managing Director, he wrote a letter to Mr. Sarkar on December 31, 1957, calling upon him to how cause why action should number be taken against him for his gross misconduct and subversive companyduct.

facts.text: On January 11, 1958, Managing Director called upon Mr. Sarkar to show cause why he should not be dismissed for insubordination

anchor.surface_text: Ultimately. the Managing Director wrote to Mr. Sarkar on January 11, 1958, that in view of the- defiant attitude adopted by him, the Managing Director was companypelled to call upon Mr. Sarkar to show cause why he should number be dismissed for his insubordination.

facts.text: On January 12, 1958, Mr. Sarkar gave elaborate explanation

anchor.surface_text: On January 12, 1958, Mr. Sarkar gave an elaborate explanation of his companyduct.

facts.text: On January 29, 1958, informed Mr. Sarkar of enquiry by Mr. S.K. Basu, Editor of Hindustan Standard, on February 1, 1958

anchor.surface_text: Since this explanation was number treated by the Managing Director as satisfactory, he informed Mr. Sarkar by his letter of January 29, 1958, that an enquiry would be held against him and that he should appear before Mr. S.K. Basu, Editor of the Hindustan Standard,

facts.text: Mr. Basu held enquiry where Mr. Sarkar cross-examined witnesses and gave evidence; question was whether he flouted lawful orders of Acting Chief Reporter

anchor.surface_text: in his room on February 1, 1958 at 1 P.M. Mr. Basu then held an enquiry into the charges already supplied to Mr. Sarkar. At this enquiry Mr. Sarkar elaborately cross-examined the witnesses who gave evidence against him and gave his own evidence.

facts.text: Enquiry officer Mr. Basu concluded on April 14, 1958 that Mr. Sarkar guilty of deliberate disobedience of lawful orders of Acting Chief Reporter

anchor.surface_text: The enquiry officer companysidered the evidence, and came to the companyclusion that Mr. Sarkar was guilty of deliberate disobedience of the lawful orders of the Acting Chief Reporter who had been properly appointed. This report was made on April 14, 1958.

facts.text: Management considered report, concluded gross misconduct, decided to discharge instead of dismiss due to long service; terminated services effective May 16, 1958

anchor.surface_text: The management of the appellant then companysidered the report, examined the evidence led at the enquiry, and came to the companyclusion that Mr. Sarkar was guilty of gross misconduct and deserved to be dismissed, but in view of the fact that he had served the Paper for a long period,

facts.text: On May 15, 1958 letter to Mr. Sarkar terminating services from May 16, one month's pay in lieu of notice, collect dues including gratuity on May 19, 1958

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, on May 15, 1958, the management wrote a letter to Mr. Sarkar that his services had been terminated with effect from May 16, 1958. Mr. Sarkar was given one months pay in lieu of numberice, and he was advised to companylect his dues, including wages earned by him, gratuity and one months pay in lieu of numberice from the cash office on May 19, 1958, at II A.M.

facts.text: Labour Court held enquiry not fair, not per natural justice, considered merits, ordered reinstatement

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, the Labour Court appears to have taken the view that the enquiry was number fair and had number been companyducted in accordance with the rules of natural justice. Having reached this companyclusion, the Tribunal proceeded to companysider the merits of the companytroversy

facts.text: Supreme Court held domestic enquiry proper, in accordance with natural justice, conclusions not perverse

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we do number think that this circumstance can render the enquiry unfair. The other criticism made by the Labour Court against the said enquiry is that some very relevant questions had been disallowed by Mr. Basu.

facts.text: Labour Court found Mr. Bhattacharjee not authorised to appoint Mr. Chakravorty

anchor.surface_text: According to the Labour Court, Mr. Bhattacharjee was number authorised to appoint Mr. Chakravorty as the Acting Chief Reporter during his period of absence on leave, and so, it thought that Mr. Chakravorty was number clothed with lawful authority

facts.text: Supreme Court found Mr. Bhattacharjee authorised per practice, appointment proper

anchor.surface_text: Thus, apart from the fact that Mr. Sarkar has number taken the oath in support of his plea, the evidence led by the appellant clearly shows that all that Mr. Bhattcharjee did on December 16, 1957 was in accordance with the prevailing practice in the institution.

facts.text: Supreme Court sets aside Labour Court order, appeal succeeds

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeal succeeds and the order passed by the Labour Court is set aside.

facts.text: Practice: Chief Reporter nominates successor during absence, evidenced in writing for Accounts Dept

anchor.surface_text: Mr. A. K. Sarkar who is the Managing Director of the Ananda Bazar Patrika has stated on oath that the usual practice in the Patrika is that when the Chief Reporter or any Head of any Section remains absent, he numberinates his successor during his absence.

facts.text: Mr. Basu was enquiry officer, Editor of Hindustan Standard

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Basu then held an enquiry into the charges already supplied to Mr. Sarkar.

issues.text: whether the Labour Court was right in holding that the enquiry conducted by Mr. Basu was not a fair enquiry

anchor.surface_text: The first question which falls for our decision is whether the Labour Court was right in holding that the enquiry conducted by Mr. Basu was not a fair enquiry. In support of this conclusion,

issues.text: whether in terminating the services of the employee the management has acted maliciously or vindictively or has been actuated by a desire to punish the employee for his trade union activities

anchor.surface_text: If the termination of an industrial employees services has been proceeded by a proper domestic enquiry which has been held in accordance with the rules of natural justice and the conclusions reached at the said, enquiry are not perverse the -Tribunal is not entitled to consider the propriety or the correctness of the said conclusions. anchor.surface_text: The principal question which was referred to the enquiry officer was whether Mr. Sarkar had flouted the lawful orders given to him by the Acting Chief Reporter? arguments.claim: Mala fides or victimisation finding requires evidence, not casual

anchor.surface_text: We have repeatedly pointed out that though industrial adjudication can and must protect industrial employees from victimisation, a finding as to mala fides or victimisation should be drawn only where evidence has been led to justify it such a finding should number be made either in a casual manner or lightheartedly.

arguments.claim: No material for unfair enquiry or mala fides by management

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, number material was produced before the Labour Court in the present proceedings to justify its finding either that the enquiry was unfair, or that the conduct of the appellant in discharging Mr. Sarkar was mala fide.

holdings.text: The extent of the jurisdiction which a Labour Court or an industrial Tribunal can exercise in dealing with such disputes is well-settled: if termination preceded by proper domestic enquiry per natural justice and conclusions not perverse, tribunal cannot interfere with findings.

anchor.surface_text: The extent of the jurisdiction which a Labour Court or an industrial Tribunal can exercise in dealing with such disputes is well-settled. If the termination of an industrial employees services has been proceeded by a proper domestic enquiry which has

The argument that the enquiry was not void due to the outsider officer and that the Labour Court correctly overruled defends the Labour Court's authority to adjudicate such issues, rebutting the holding by implying competence over aspects of the merits.
Argument presents contrary evidence rebutting victimisation by showing standard practices and no qualifying incident.
Argument cites contrary evidence, lack of incident, and witness testimony supporting the holding of no malice.
Argument provides evidence on appointment practices and lack of supporting incidents, addressing the malice/vindictiveness issue.
Argument that refusal contravened natural justice attacks the claim that it did not violate natural justice due to irrelevance
Argument that refusal violated natural justice rebuts the holding by challenging the propriety of the domestic enquiry
Argument emphasizing evidence requirement for Mala Fides supports the concept's stipulation that it not be found casually.
